title: Rear Brake Master Cylinder - Removal

body.body: Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
Rear Master Cyl Remove - LJ2; LK2
To prevent paint damage, do not spill brake fluid onto any area of the bodywork.
Spilled brake fluid will damage paintwork.
You will need to remove the rear brake caliper and push the pistons out to back bleed the master cylinder as part of the brake bleeding procedure, see
Remove the right outrigger cover panel (see
Make sure you do not damage the brake pad material when you move the brake pads.
If the brake pads to come into contact with each other or sharp objects, the material can crack or break.
Damage to the brake pads may result in reduced braking efficiency
Failure to follow the advice above may lead to loss of motorcycle control which could result in serious injury or death.

Use a suitable flat metal plate approximately 2 mm thick and 30 to 50 mm wide (for example a gasket scraper) between the brake pads, pump the rear brake pedal slowly until the plate is held by the brake pads. Do not allow the pistons to fall out.
Disconnect the rear brake switch from the main harness.
When you disconnect the brake hose from the master cylinder, keep the open end of the hose above the height of the rear brake master cylinder.
Allowing the brake hose to fall below the rear brake master cylinder height will allow an excessive amount of air to enter into the brake system.
Trapped air may cause the brake lever to feel spongy and reduce braking efficiency.
Note the orientation of the brake hose to the master cylinder.
Disconnect the brake hose from the master cylinder. Discard the sealing washers and allow the brake fluid to drain from the master cylinder outlet into a suitable container.
Remove and discard the rear master cylinder reservoir fixing and support the reservoir.

body.name: Right Control Plate and Rear Master Cylinder_TP0657

body.body: Remove the two fixings and remove the right hand control plate and rear brake master cylinder assembly.
Remove the two fixings and remove the rear brake switch and bracket from the control plate, noting the routing of the electrical harness for installation.
Note the position and orientation of the clevis pin and clip for installation.
Remove the clip and clevis pin at the lower end of the brake push rod.
Remove the two fixings and remove the master cylinder from the control plate.
Disconnect the reservoir hose from the master cylinder if required and collect any brake fluid.
